column3: Great job passing the tests!
Nice job converting the alphabet from string to list!
There must be in-line comments, especially for complex bits of code.
Try to ensure that comments are never more than 80 characters long!
Dictionaries are great because of how quickly we can access values via their keys. We don't need typically need extra indexing structures to access values in a dictionary, just the keys as index!
It was required to write tests for questions 1-3
example_year_db2(): Need to add data (likely so you can test missing years/names).
split or trim didn't pass our unit tests - it's important to test your functions before using them. Come to student help hours if you don't know how!
Works, except for proper handling of splitting an empty string.
Removes the newline at the end, but also removes other whitespace.
Good job iterating over each year in years!
Must check that a key exists in the dictionary before accessing it.
When a name does not exist in the dict, it makes more sense to add a 0 to the output list.
It's more efficient to iterate over the arg years, and use that as keys, rather than check each key in year_table if it matches a given year (this may also return data out of order!)
Must return a list of 26 counts, not just the counts of letters that exist in the given dict.
Using nested loops inefficient here: iterate over names in name_table, adding first char count to letter_freqs dict. Then at end, make list by iterating over sorted(letter_freqs).

Remember, dictionaries are not ordered! For small values like what we have here, they _appear_ sorted, but this may not always be the case. It's a good idea to iterate over sorted(letter_freq) as the keys so you _know_ the list you produce is grabbing values in the correct order.
Nice job ensuring the dict output is sorted!
Frequency counts should be on the Y-axis, the other data is the X-axis.
Good job calling functions previously written in the plotting functions!
No need to loop of years for y-values. Just use years directly!
Nice call on list('ABC...XYZ')!
list('ABC...XYZ') might be simpler!
